docs.snippet: California legislators turned up the heat on power generating companies today, citing two of them for not handing over documents necessary in the state's continuing hearings on the spike in electricity prices.     A special legislative panel, call...
docs.lead_paragraph: California legislators turned up the heat on power generating companies today, citing two of them for not handing over documents necessary in the state's continuing hearings on the spike in electricity prices. A special legislative panel, called the Senate Select Committee to Investigate Market Manipulation, unanimously passed a contempt motion this afternoon saying that the Mirant Corporation, based in Atlanta, and the Enron Corporation, based in Houston, had failed to respond to a June 11 subpoena asking for documents.
docs.abstract: California legislators put intense pressure on power generating companies, citing two of them for not handing over documents necessary in state's continuing hearings on spike in electricity prices; special legislative panel, called Senate Select Committee to Investigate Market Manipulation, unanimously passes contempt motion saying that Mirant Corp, based in Atlanta, and Enron Corp, based in Houston, failed to respond to June 11 subpoena asking for documents (M)

headline.main: California Cites Generators For Withholding Documents

docs.snippet: Enron Energie G.m.b.H., a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation of Houston, has won the right to supply electricity in Germany after Elektromark, the country's grid operator, withdrew its previous objections to such an agreement.    Elektromark said...
docs.lead_paragraph: Enron Energie G.m.b.H., a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation of Houston, has won the right to supply electricity in Germany after Elektromark, the country's grid operator, withdrew its previous objections to such an agreement. Elektromark said last year that it would deny Enron access to supply a local energy distributor, Stadtwerke Ludenscheid. Enron then approached the German Cartel Office, complaining of a restraint of trade. Under a European Union directive, member nations must open at least 25 percent of their electricity markets to competition by February.
docs.abstract: Enron Energie GmbH, subsidiary of Enron Corp, wins right to supply electricity in Germany after Elektromark, country's grid operator, withdraws its previous objections to such an agreement (S)

headline.main: Enron Wins German Power Supply Deal

docs.snippet: India's western state of Maharashtra seemed ready today to revive a $2.8 billion power project by the Enron Corporation of Houston that it scrapped just nine weeks ago.    "The project is being revived," Maharashtra's chief minister, Manohar Joshi...
docs.lead_paragraph: India's western state of Maharashtra seemed ready today to revive a $2.8 billion power project by the Enron Corporation of Houston that it scrapped just nine weeks ago. "The project is being revived," Maharashtra's chief minister, Manohar Joshi, told reporters after a cabinet meeting today.

headline.main: Enron Project Is Reconsidered in India

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation and Gazprom, Russia's main natural-gas company, agreed yesterday to work together to deliver Russian natural gas and to develop projects to use the gas in European countries. Enron, based in Houston, operates 44,000 miles of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation and Gazprom, Russia's main natural-gas company, agreed yesterday to work together to deliver Russian natural gas and to develop projects to use the gas in European countries. Enron, based in Houston, operates 44,000 miles of pipelines and is one of the largest independent power producers, operating gas-fired electric generators in the United States and Britain.

headline.main: ENRON AND RUSSIAN GAS PRODUCER TO JOIN FORCES

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation said that the Royal Bank of Scotland had agreed to pay $41.8 million and forfeit some claims in its bankruptcy case to settle a lawsuit....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation, the energy trader trying to reorganize in bankruptcy, said yesterday that the Royal Bank of Scotland had agreed to pay $41.8 million and forfeit some claims in the bankruptcy case to settle a lawsuit. In exchange, Enron will pay Royal Bank of Scotland $20 million to resolve $329 million in claims the bank filed against the energy trader, the Houston-based company said in a statement.

headline.main: Enron and Royal Bank of Scotland Settle Lawsuit

docs.snippet: An article in Business Day yesterday about potential conflict among creditors of Enron -- Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase versus others -- misstated Citigroup's involvement with the committee of unsecured creditors in Enron's bankruptcy case. Cit...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day yesterday about potential conflict among creditors of Enron -- Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase versus others -- misstated Citigroup's involvement with the committee of unsecured creditors in Enron's bankruptcy case. Citigroup resigned from the committee on May 30, 2002; it is no longer a member.
docs.abstract: Correction of July 30 article on potential conflict among creditors of Enron; Citigroup resigned from committee of unsecured creditors in Enron bankruptcy case on May 30, '02

docs.snippet: In the year before the Enron Corporation collapsed last December, about 100 executives and energy traders collected more than $300 million in cash payments from the company, according to documents filed today in bankruptcy court.    More than $100...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the year before the Enron Corporation collapsed last December, about 100 executives and energy traders collected more than $300 million in cash payments from the company, according to documents filed today in bankruptcy court. More than $100 million -- much of it previously disclosed in the form of salary, bonuses and loans -- went to Kenneth L. Lay, the company's former chairman and chief executive.
docs.abstract: Documents filed in bankruptcy court show year before Enron Corp collapsed last December, about 100 executives and energy traders collected more than $300 million in cash payments from company; more than $100 million went to former chairman-chief executive Kenneth L Lay; majority of cash payments went to employees at units whose profitability has been called into question since company's collapse; John J Lavorato, top executive at Enron's energy-trading unit, and gas trader John D Arnold each received cash bonuses of $8 million to keep them from leaving Enron last fall; former chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling received $7.5 million in cash bonuses and incentive pay; Lay got $10.6 million in similar payments; former Enron Energy Services executive David W Delainey received $4.2 million; Senate Finance Committee says it is looking into whether top executives at Enron placed their bonuses in offshore accounts and had later withdrawn that money without paying taxes; chart (M)

headline.main: Officials Got a Windfall Before Enron's Collapse

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Spreading the Blame at Andersen,'' by James O'Toole (Op-Ed, March 26):...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Spreading the Blame at Andersen,'' by James O'Toole (Op-Ed, March 26):
docs.abstract: Garry Grasinski letter scores March 26 James O'Toole article for condemning all employees of Arthur Andersen when only handful committed any wrongdoing

docs.snippet: Jeffrey K. Skilling proclaimed his innocence again yesterday, but in the process he joined in the chorus of people who believe that something was rotten at Enron, the company he formerly ran.    ''Unlike so many others so much less fortunate than ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey K. Skilling proclaimed his innocence again yesterday, but in the process he joined in the chorus of people who believe that something was rotten at Enron, the company he formerly ran. ''Unlike so many others so much less fortunate than me, I am not a victim here,'' Mr. Skilling testified at a Senate hearing. ''But also unlike others, I am not one of the perpetrators either.''
docs.abstract: Analysis of Enron Corp former chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling's testimony before Senate committee; says Skilling did not offer his opinion as to who perpetrators were and recurring theme in his testimony was that he is not an accountant; holds Skilling has not picked up much in way of humility since Enron Corp, blaming banks for Enron's collapse because they were not willing to keep lending billions; photo of Skilling with Enron president Jeffrey McMahon and Skilling's lawyer Bruce Hiler (M)

headline.main: The World According to Enron's Ex-Chief

docs.snippet: The first of at least 11 Congressional hearings into the largest corporate bankruptcy in United States history begins tomorrow. Although Enron's executives and accountants have much to answer for, they can be forgiven for cracking a wry smile when...
docs.lead_paragraph: The first of at least 11 Congressional hearings into the largest corporate bankruptcy in United States history begins tomorrow. Although Enron's executives and accountants have much to answer for, they can be forgiven for cracking a wry smile when members of Congress begin lecturing them on their dereliction of duty: Congress itself, as much as Enron and Arthur Andersen, bears some responsibility for the current state of affairs. The story begins in the 1970's and 1980's, when members of Congress, most from oil-producing states, pressured the Financial Accounting Standards Board and the Securities and Exchange Commission not to demand tougher standards for financial reporting in the petroleum industry. At the time, it was clear that the lawmakers were serving corporate interests, not those of investors. Now it's clear that this was only a warm-up act.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Michael H Granof and Stephen A Zeff on upcoming Congressional hearings into Enron Corp bankruptcy says Congress itself, as much as Enron and Arthur Andersen accounting firm, bears some responsibility for not demanding tougher standards for corporate financial reporting; history of how Congress set stage for Enron's failure reviewed (M)

byline.original: By Michael H. Granof and Stephen A. Zeff
